item.title: Recognizing June 19, 2017, as this year's observance of the historical significance of Juneteenth Independence Day.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

item.title: Recognizing June 19, 2018, as this year's observance of the historical significance of Juneteenth Independence Day.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

item.title: A resolution designating June 19, 2017, as "Juneteenth Independence Day" in recognition of June 19, 1865, the date on which slavery legally came to an end in the United States.

latestAction.text: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S4695)

item.title: A resolution designating June 19, 2018, as "Juneteenth Independence Day" in recognition of June 19, 1865, the date on which slavery legally came to an end in the United States.

latestAction.text: Submitted in the Senate, considered, and agreed to without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent. (consideration: CR S3958; text: CR S3954)

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

policyArea.name: Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues
Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues

summary.text:
Expresses support for the designation of Juneteenth Independence Day.

Recognizes the historical significance and supports the continued celebration of Juneteenth Independence Day, which commemorates the end of slavery in the United States.

bill.title: Expressing support for designation of June 19, 2018, as "Juneteenth Independence Day" in recognition of June 19, 1865, the date on which slavery legally came to an end in the United States.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
